text:
How would you go about increasing the display size of a seaborn boxplot in jupyter? Having trouble finding a straightforward solution on stackoverflow and figsize does not seem to work. My code below:

```ax = sns.boxplot(x ="loans_taken", y = "nr_of_entrepreneurs", hue = "customer_status",
                 data = dloans, palette = "Set3", figsize=(15, 10))```

elements.text: How would you go about increasing the display size of a seaborn boxplot in jupyter? Having trouble finding a straightforward solution on stackoverflow and figsize does not seem to work. My code below:

ax = sns.boxplot(x ="loans_taken", y = "nr_of_entrepreneurs", hue = "customer_status",
                 data = dloans, palette = "Set3", figsize=(15, 10))

text:
i always use
```fig, ax = plt.subplots(figsize=(10,10))  # or any other size
sns.boxplot(data=..., x=...., ax=ax)```

elements.text: i always use

fig, ax = plt.subplots(figsize=(10,10))  # or any other size
sns.boxplot(data=..., x=...., ax=ax)

text:
but I am looking at your code here and wondering if it is correct - normally in a box plot theres one category (ie what separates the boxes from eachother) and one value (ie the range of numbers per box) whereas your x and y both sound like numerical data, am i right?
• unless nr_of_entrepreneurs is a bucket, like <10, 10-50, 50+ etc 
this might explain why the boxplot is hard to see ?

elements.text: but I am looking at your code here and wondering if it is correct - normally in a box plot theres one category (ie what separates the boxes from eachother) and one value (ie the range of numbers per box) whereas your x and y both sound like numerical data, am i right?
unless nr_of_entrepreneurs is a bucket, like <10, 10-50, 50+ etc
this might explain why the boxplot is hard to see ?

text:
<!channel>,
I was on a call with one of you. Pandas didn't like this query string in a `read_sql_query()` statement:
```'''SELECT t.account_id as accounts, date_format(convert(t.date,date), '%Y') as year, d.A2 as district_name, d.A3 as region, round(sum(t.amount)) as total_trans FROM trans t join account a on a.account_id = t.account_id join district d on t.account_id = d.A1 group by accounts, district_name, region, year'''```
it gives an
```pd.read_sql - Unsupported format character error (0x27)```
the problem is this `'%Y'`  expression in the date_format clause. It can be solved using the `sqlalchemy.text()`  function like this:

```import sqlalchmey as sa

# here you define your engine
###
# define the sql query

my_query_string = '''SELECT t.account_id as accounts, date_format(convert(t.date,date), '%Y') as year, d.A2 as district_name, d.A3 as region, round(sum(t.amount)) as total_trans FROM trans t join account a on a.account_id = t.account_id join district d on t.account_id = d.A1 group by accounts, district_name, region, year'''

# read the table from the sql query into a dataframe
# using sa.text()

df = pd.read_sql_query(sa.text(my_query_string), engine)```
check <https://stackoverflow.com/questions/66529964/pd-read-sql-unsupported-format-character-error-0x27|this> stackoverflow posting

search words for google: "pd read_sql_query unsupported format character error (0x27) query string"
